comments.body: [~usrivast] : Please mention target and load type in your ER description and summary; so that it's easy to identify the right owner for this.

Target is ADLS. 
Load type : Unload

[~rdhuvad] 

[~agauniya]

[~usrivast] : Can you please let us know if customer system is SAP ECC or SAP S4 HANA?

If system is SAP ECC, Table for which customer is facing this problem is pool table, cluster table or transparent table?

Also check agent location if that is present in different geo location than the SAP system location.

 

There is a guide on SAP SLT performance (I am still checking this doc) : [https://help.sap.com/doc/04989b617c6f4ca8982fde703e7350f9/2.0.14/en-US/SLT%20Performance%20Guide.pdf]

Check if performance option set to "Performance optimized" and it is improving performance?

[~gomahesh] 

This is S4 HANA system and Table is ACDOCA.

SAP team has confirmed the Performance optimized option is already set and both IICS as well as SAP servers are located in NA, Virginia.

[~usrivast] : The data fetch for the first time is taking a long time(~2 hours, this might be bringing the average data transfer time down). I also observe that subsequent calls are taking relatively less time(~800 ms). This looks to be an issue from SAP instance side.

I think increasing the fetch size here should help(initial call talking too long could still be there). The logs attached both have fetch size set to 8, do you have logs for bigger fetch size?
I would like to have a follow up on this ER, please let me know if there is any update?
I would like to have a follow up on this ER, please let me know if there is any update?

[~rdhuvad] 

[~ppanigra] 
We increased the fetch size it did not help, I will get back to you with logs on increased fetch size.

[~asbhatt] 

PFA the log with bigger fetch size.

Logs : [ER-26426|https://informatica-my.sharepoint.com/:f:/p/usrivast/Eqjkh-u7I5pGhxfQm203xh4BqhhnyO-ctG_f8qbTu32PGA?e=Hg4fDS]

[~asbhatt] [~ppanigra] 

Seems we are capped by : *maximumReadArraySize* [http://codecrawler/dbmi/xref/appmiconnectors/src/ML/components/adapters/sap/src/main/java/com/infa/rat/appmi/sap/unload/reader/SAPSingleUnload.java#237]



Analysis :



There is a source custom property : unloadMaximumReadArraySize

 

In the UI, Source page, look for option to set Custom Properties. Add this "Source" Custom Property:

"unloadMaximumReadArraySize" with value "2000" would set the default value.

 

unloadMaximumReadArraySize -- this can help in tuning the batch read size.

 

Per the logs, when we changed the fetch size the number of elements in the queue increased from 1093 to 73191.

But the batch fetch done from the DBMI framework is still set to 2000, which means we will read data from the ODP Extractor and put it in the buffers but then we read these records in batches of 2k and prepare that for unloading.

 

Also, with changes on fetch size, the initial fetch has also become faster,

In old jobs it was :

2024-01-24 02:58:11,103 [UNLOAD-SLT7eDCH500-ACDOCA InputEndpoint Helper(417914)] LEVEL_1 trace - Adapter <SAP> Retrieved data successfully. Total time taken: *5153956* ms.

 

In new job :

2024-02-02 11:22:35,148 [UNLOAD-SLT7eDCH500-ACDOCA InputEndpoint Helper(492934)] LEVEL_1 trace - Adapter <SAP> Retrieved data successfully. Total time taken: *532500* ms.

 

This is more than 10x improved for execution.

At this point, I would recommend making unloadMaximumReadArraySize to 10k (suggest if you want to see different values) and observing for 30 minutes if the performance improves then we can tune further, and we can find the rate from the logs.

Currently, the performance is 2-3 seconds for 2k fetches.
[~usrivast] we will revert back on this.
[~usrivast] : "unloadMaximumReadArraySize" this property usage looks good. But the core problem remains, ie. initial fetch time is still taking time.

Their initial fetch is close to 9 minutes or so.

2024-02-14 07:38:17,330 [CDC-UNLOAD-SLT7eDCH500.FAGLFLEXA InputEndpoint Helper(102791)] LEVEL_1 trace - Adapter <SAP> Retrieved data successfully. Total time taken: 527903 ms.

I don' think this is too much most time we have spent parsing through result set.

Overall I think setting that to 20k has improved performance.

Planning to test this further by making batch a 100k in size.

Let me know your thoughts.

New logs attached : [ER-26426|https://informatica-my.sharepoint.com/:f:/p/usrivast/Eqjkh-u7I5pGhxfQm203xh4BqhhnyO-ctG_f8qbTu32PGA?e=faHIk7] 

!image-2024-02-15-17-46-06-959.png!

 

[~asbhatt]
I would like to have a follow up on this ER, please let me know if there is any update?
Hi [~usrivast] are we good to close this ER?
[~ppanigra] / [~asbhatt] : Can we review this to see what's next step?

[~usrivast] we discussed this at GCS syncup and verified that this is good to be closed. Do let me know if you have any concerns.

cc [~rnagulav]
I would like to have a follow up on this ER, please let me know if there is any update?

[~rdhuvad] 
We are still having this issue and due to the changes we are running into OOM issues, so we were scaling up the DBMI JVM size.

 

[~ppanigra] 

[~asbhatt]
I would like to have a follow up on this ER, please let me know if there is any update?

[~rdhuvad] 

Even after scaling up the DBMI JVM size to 16GB with 100k batch size, Job is failing with OutOfMemoryError. It is not even dumping any .hprof file even after setting -XX:+HeapDumpOnOutOfMemoryError. Customer is still looking for better performance. They are looking around 6 times faster load than with 50k batch size load. 50k batch size took around 36 hours to complete 53 million records. Any further suggestion on this one?

cc: [~usrivast] [~ppanigra] [~asbhatt]

[~jmehta]: We usually recommend to have JVM heap size to at least 32GB if we've unload tasks and high volume data. In terms of performance expectations, do we know if they already tried using CDI with SAP ODP connector? If so, how much time it took compare to CMI? If CDI is taking pretty much same amount of time, then mostly that's the limitation from SAP/ODP itself; but if CDI is much faster, we can certainly review to see if any bottleneck with CMI while using ODP.

hi [~jmehta] 

There are a few options that they could try:

1. In the Administration UI, edit the secure agent runtime environment, adding custom config entry for environment variable DBMI_TASK_OVERRIDE_PROPERTIES pointing to a local text file.

For example: DBMI_AGENT_ENV  DBMI_TASK_OVERRIDE_PROPERTIES  D:\infa\DBMITaskOverrideProperties.txt

Create a text file D:\infa\DBMITaskOverrideProperties.txt with the below line:
alljobs.flushTimeout=10000000

2. In source custom properties, set unloadHelperThreadCount=4 along with unloadMaximumReadArraySize.

3. In target custom properties, set the below:
  writerHelperThreadCount=4
  writerFlatUnloadAsyncLoading=true

4. In runtime options, increase number of rows in output file to 1000000.

[~agauniya] 
We tested these configs and they did not help the run.

Attaching the logs for the same.

I also see a lot of new messages :
GET LAST CHECKPOINT called on thread CDC-UNLOAD-SLT7eDCH500.ACDOCA ADLSGen2File Writer(194)

[^mi_OneS4_CDL0_CDC_Adhoc_ACDOCA_IC_4709-CDC-UNLOAD-SLT7eDCH500.ACDOCA-9e865bce7c6a4919b28e56cde96d66e3.log]

And most time seems to be spent in : processing records from queue.

One sample from log :

2024-03-13 12:26:49,748 [CDC-UNLOAD-SLT7eDCH500.ACDOCA InputEndpoint Helper(207)] LEVEL_1 trace - Adapter <SAP> Number of records read in the result set: 38144. Time taken to process the result set: 16026 ms.
2024-03-13 12:26:49,750 [CDC-UNLOAD-SLT7eDCH500.ACDOCA InputEndpoint Helper(207)] LEVEL_1 trace - Adapter <SAP> Start processing records from queue. Current Queue size: 107921.
2024-03-13 12:27:41,169 [CDC-UNLOAD-SLT7eDCH500.ACDOCA ADLSGen2File Writer(194)] LEVEL_1 trace - GET LAST CHECKPOINT called on thread CDC-UNLOAD-SLT7eDCH500.ACDOCA ADLSGen2File Writer(194)
2024-03-13 12:28:41,695 [CDC-UNLOAD-SLT7eDCH500.ACDOCA ADLSGen2File Writer(194)] LEVEL_1 trace - GET LAST CHECKPOINT called on thread CDC-UNLOAD-SLT7eDCH500.ACDOCA ADLSGen2File Writer(194)
2024-03-13 12:29:03,756 [CDC-UNLOAD-SLT7eDCH500.ACDOCA InputEndpoint Helper(207)] LEVEL_1 trace - Adapter <SAP> Number of rows read in this iteration: 100000. Total rows read so far: 500000.
2024-03-13 12:29:04,790 [CDC-UNLOAD-SLT7eDCH500.ACDOCA InputEndpoint Helper(207)] LEVEL_1 trace - Adapter <SAP> Start read iteration: 6
2024-03-13 12:29:04,790 [CDC-UNLOAD-SLT7eDCH500.ACDOCA InputEndpoint Helper(207)] LEVEL_1 trace - Adapter <SAP> Fill queue. Current Queue size: 7921.

Adding Message from CSM (Akshat ) to PM, indicating customer expecting or need/wants to run this job under 10 hours.  Customer was actually questing if SAP ODP Extractor is preparing data around 2 and 30 minutes  to be read...so they expecting  Informatica MI job to read the entire data set and write in around the same amount of time and upon pressing it may not possible they expressed at least with 10 hours.

Is this expectation achievable ? what configuration we need to set to achieve  through MI ?.

 

PS: Attaching email message
[~rdhuvad]  as discussed, please have internal sync and share your inputs on next steps.

Thanks [~sureddy]; I'm discussing this internally and get ER updated.

[~usrivast] : Do you know if customer will be fine to try out the Hex2Ascii optimization if we make it available to them? As we don't have the volume that customer has, it will be difficult for us to test it completely (though we can certainly validate it with whatever large table we've before delivering).

CC: [~gomahesh], [~ppanigra], [~agauniya]

[~usrivast] : Note that many folks are on floating holiday today; so next update will be tomorrow.

CC: [~sureddy]
Checking it on priority.
Suggestion given by perf team is implemented and QA is trying out the same.

[~gomahesh] 

[~rdhuvad] 
We are down to 8 hours with CDI and 3 partitions at this point, this testing was done without a target where the customer is using a filter to drop all records read from the source so any delay on ADLS side has not come into picture here.

[~usrivast] : Sorry, I'm struggling to understand your above comment; would you mind rephrase it? "down to 8 hours with CDI" – from earlier how many hours? "3 partitions" – so what's number with single partition?

[~rdhuvad] 

 "down to 8 hours with CDI" – from earlier how many hours? ---> Earlier we took ~20 hours

"3 partitions" – so what's number with single partition? ---> 20 hours

[~usrivast] : With single partition, performance of CDI and MI is same? 

MI SAP ODP currently don't support partitioning.

Note: We added hecToAscii change, but that improved performance 2-3% only.
I would like to have a follow up on this ER, please let me know if there is any update?

[~gomahesh] 
the performance for CDI was ~20 hours and MI was 30+ hours.
So, not same.

 

[~rdhuvad]

[~agauniya] : As per [~gomahesh]'s comment above, hexToAscii optimization is resulting only 2-3% improvement; is that expected or we are expecting more gain here? If latter, can we check in profiler where we still have bottleneck?

Hi [~rdhuvad] - hexToAscii started to perform 2X faster, but unfortunately it did not have an impact on overall runtime. The maximum improvement I saw was 7-8%. I have profiled the session again and Reader is still the major bottleneck. As highlighted in the snapshot, we spend 66% time in Reader (out of which generateDML is the top hotspot)

!Hotspot1.png|width=743,height=256!

Thanks [~agauniya] !

[~gomahesh] : Are we able to see any opportunity to optimize generateDML logic?

[~rdhuvad] : As per snapshot above 33% time taken by setValue of HelperDmlBuilderDataValue, and within that major time is taken by getColumn which is just unmodifiable list (normal list just that on modification of the list it throws the exception), here I don't see any scope of improvement.

 

[~agauniya]
[~gomahesh] : I believe this entire generateDML logic is generic across different sources? If so, [~agauniya] aren't we observing similar spike with other sources?

hi [~rdhuvad] - We have mostly benchmarked and profiled DBMI sources so far, and I could not find any similar method in those profiled sessions. I will run an unload case with Salesforce source and share the observations.
Thanks [~agauniya] ! [~gomahesh] : Any thoughts here?

[~rdhuvad] : DBMI Sources are JDBC based, and logic of unload is different, in those sources also DML is being prepared, but method name etc. is different.

 

[~agauniya] : In case of DBMI Sources, dml preparation logic is part of method 

readJDBCReaderResultSet of class DataSourceReadHelper.java. below is the line for get column.

final Payload.SchemaColumn column = schema.getColumn(i);

[~gomahesh] - I see a similar method in an oracle to snowflake unload job but it is taking negligible time.

!image-2024-04-19-09-32-21-460.png|width=633,height=280!
[~agauniya] : ok, Can you check with salesforce if behavior is same with salesforce?
I would like to have a follow up on this ER, please let me know if there is any update?

Hi [~gomahesh]/ [~rdhuvad] - I profiled a session with salesforce source and adls target. As per the below snapshot, even though generateDML came as the top hotspot in this case as well, the underlying methods are not the same.

!image-2024-04-29-11-09-58-343.png|width=772,height=290!

There was one difference in the schema of the source tables - ODP source had >150 columns whereas the salesforce source had just 30 columns. Therefore I also profiled another ODP to ADLS unload task where source had only 17 columns. As highlighted in the below screenshot, generateDML did not appear as the top hotspot. 

!image-2024-04-29-11-17-31-731.png|width=747,height=367!

There is an additional observation on how adjustments in fetch size impact the bottleneck within the ODP to ADLS SLT job with >150 columns.

With the default fetch size set at 8MB, the RfcDestination.execute() function emerges as the primary contributor to runtime. 

!image-2024-04-29-11-44-05-872.png|width=782,height=389!

However, upon increasing the fetch size (from 8MB to 500MB) and adding unloadMaximumReadArraySize=4000 as a custom property (similar settings as customer), generateDML becomes the primary hotspot.
[~agauniya] : just for information, 500MB does not make sense, Max limit is 50MB, if you pass more than this, SAP ignore its and use 50MB.
I would like to have a follow up on this ER, please let me know if there is any update?
[~agauniya] / [~gomahesh] : Can we update with latest findings?

[~rdhuvad] : with hextoascii improvement, [~agauniya] observed without partition if we compare CDI ODP extractor with appmi ODP extractor, appmi one is bit faster. She will test few more scenarios, then we will update the result.

 

[~ppanigra]

[~agauniya] 
Attached the CDI log as discussed on Team.

Hi [~rdhuvad] - Please find the below comparison of APPMI and CDI in our setup, I couldn't replicate the scenario where CDI outperformed APPMI. 
|*Use case* |*Num of columns*|*Data Volume*|*Appmi runtime (before HexToAscii fix)*|*Appmi runtime (after HexToAscii fix)*|*CDI runtime*|*Observation*|
|ODP → ADLS|17|2.04 Mn (Non SLT)|0:26:16|0:20:06|0:25:48|~20% faster than CDI after HexToAscii fix|
|ODP → ADLS|163|5 Mn (SLT replication)|0:58:05|0:54:42|0:55:01|On par with CDI after HexToAscii fix|

In tests involving a single partition, APPMI consistently performed equally or slightly better than CDI, especially after implementing the hexToAscii fix. However, CDI performs a lot faster after enabling source partitioning.

To eliminate any potential target-side overhead, I conducted tests with an S3 minio target installed on the same machine as the secure agent, the results were same.
Hi [~usrivast] - Could you please share the latest updates from the customer on this ER?

[~agauniya] : That's fantastic! Thank you so much for help finding HexToAscii optimization! I agree we should enable partitioning with SAP ODP as we are able to see much better numbers in CDI in that mode. [~braghave] / [~dhsinha] : Can we please track this via Epic?

CC: [~eafriat] , [~tmorel]
[~usrivast] : Please raise CFR as appropriate to support partitioning with AppMI SAP ODP source.
